newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's LOMO swings into H1 loss.
newsitem.headline: Russia's LOMO swings into H1 loss.

text.p: NOTES - Full name AO Leningradskoye Optiko-Mekhanicheskoye Obyedineniye. Inros-Kapital owns 20 percent.
Lazar Zalmanov, assistant to chief executive, told Reuters the loss reflected a re-evaluation of assets, higher energy prices and planned export receipts in the second half.
"By the end of the year everything will be back to normal," he said. In 1995 LOMO had a profit before tax of 21.7 billion roubles, up from 9.3 billion in 1994.

These figures are not prepared to international accounting standards but to Russian accounting standards, which differ significantly from those normally supplied in the West. Russian accounts are designed to meet the requirements of the tax authorities. Russian companies can choose whether to show revenues and spending on a cash or accruals basis. Definitions of profit and assets differ significantly from those in the West, and converting Russian accounts to international standards can turn a profit into a loss.
Figures are not adjusted for inflation or the depreciation of the rouble, but the following data may be helpful.
